issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: hive CLI can't handle hadoop dfs command  with space and quotes.

comments.body:
The root cause is in DfsProcessor class.
Hive parses command via a simple split("\\s+"), which won't handle the space between quotes or ignore special characters ("/') in the path.
What can we do in the way of unit testing. Either via junit or by the .q system?
It looks good but add some type testing to ensure feature does not break in the future.
add a query file for junit
add a query file for unit test for my patch
[~appodictic],could you help to review the new patch? Thank you
Hey sorry I missed this. Is it possible to add an dfs -ls command in here? The reason I say this is because the .q.out has no output.
Re-uploading for tests

ATTACHMENT ID: 12596273

[~bingl]
Sorry about the delay in getting your patch in.
Looks like the patch didn't apply properly on trunk.
I took a look at the patch, I think it would be better to use this library - http://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-lang/javadocs/api-2.4/org/apache/commons/lang/text/StrTokenizer.html#StrTokenizer(java.lang.String, org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrMatcher, org.apache.commons.lang.text.StrMatcher) .
We already include that library in hive. Reusing it would mean the chances of bugs are lower.

As [~appodictic] mentioned, can you also include "dfs -ls " commands that show the files in output ? (Or any command that verifies that the files got created as expected).

Hi, [~thejas]
Thank you for your comments.
I tried StrTokenizer, seems it only can handle part of scenarios, like

dfs -mkdir "hello world"   // StrTokenizer(cmd,splitDel,doubleQuo)
dfs -mkdir 'hello world"   // StrTokenizer(cmd,splitDel,singleQuo)

But can't handle the wrong input. like
dfs -mkdir "abd'db"abe' "   // " and ' are not matched

Let me know if I missed something.

Thank you!
Re-create the patch file based on the latest code in trunk

Hi, [~thejas]
I generated a new patch for this defect, also fixed a bug in my previous patch.
Could you help to review it?

Thank you!

ATTACHMENT ID: 12728375 - PreCommit-HIVE-TRUNK-Build
The failure should not related to this patch.

Hi, [~thejas]
Could you review the patch again? Thanks a lot!
Removing fix version of 1.2.1 since this is not part of the already-released 1.2.1 release. Please set appropriate commit version when this fix is committed.

I submitted a review request manually.
The link is https://reviews.apache.org/r/38199/

Hadoop FsShell is passed in token[] using GenericOptionsParser to parse the string. https://github.com/apache/hadoop/blob/release-2.6.0/hadoop-common-project/hadoop-common/src/main/java/org/apache/hadoop/util/ToolRunner.java#L64 
I think instead of adding custom splitCmd() to parse it, using GenericOptionsParser will make us consistent with Hadoop's parsing code.

Hi, [~ashutoshc]
Thank you for your suggestion, I'm afraid we can't use GenericOptionsParser in Hive.

In hadoop, before it runs into FsShell.main(), Linux shell already parses the parameters.
When it calls 
res = ToolRunner.run(shell, argv);  // " or ' already been removed from argv

For example,
[root@localhost bin]# hadoop fs -ls "ha ah"
/usr/jdk64/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.45-28.b13.el6_6.x86_64/bin/java ... org.apache.hadoop.fs.FsShell -ls ha ah
[root@localhost bin]# hadoop fs -ls 'a'
/usr/jdk64/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.45-28.b13.el6_6.x86_64/bin/java ... org.apache.hadoop.fs.FsShell -ls a

While in Hive, after launch HiveCLI, org.apache.hadoop.hive.cli.CliDriver will handle the left inputs.
Which means that the java class in Hive should parse the input with " or ' by itself.

That's the reason I added a customized splitCmd() method.

Thank you,
Bing

Hi, [~ashutoshc]
Thank you for your suggestion, I'm afraid we can't use GenericOptionsParser in Hive.

In hadoop, before it runs into FsShell.main(), Linux shell already parses the parameters.
When it calls 
res = ToolRunner.run(shell, argv);  // " or ' already been removed from argv

For example,
[root@localhost bin]# hadoop fs -ls "ha ah"
/usr/jdk64/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.45-28.b13.el6_6.x86_64/bin/java ... org.apache.hadoop.fs.FsShell -ls ha ah
[root@localhost bin]# hadoop fs -ls 'a'
/usr/jdk64/java-1.8.0-openjdk-1.8.0.45-28.b13.el6_6.x86_64/bin/java ... org.apache.hadoop.fs.FsShell -ls a

While in Hive, after launch HiveCLI, org.apache.hadoop.hive.cli.CliDriver will handle the left inputs.
Which means that the java class in Hive should parse the input with " or ' by itself.

That's the reason I added a customized splitCmd() method.

Thank you,
Bing
[~libing] thanks a lot for the patch and apologies that this went out of sight. Would you like to rebase it one more time for master? I am +1 on the changes.
